/*
Everyone knows Fibonacci sequence, it was studied deeply by mathematicians in 
the last couple centuries. However, what people don't know is Tribonacci sequence.
Tribonacci sequence is defined by the recurrence:
tri(1) = 3
tri(n) = 1 + n / 2, if n is even.
tri(n) =  tri(n - 1) + tri(n - 2) + tri(n + 1), if n is odd.
For example:
tri(2) = 1 + (2 / 2) = 2
tri(4) = 3
tri(3) = tri(2) + tri(1) + tri(4)
       = 2 + 3 + 3 = 8 
You are given a non-negative integer number n, you have to a return a vector of the 
first n + 1 numbers of the Tribonacci sequence.
Examples:

<|endoftext|>/*
The Brazilian factorial is defined as:
brazilian_factorial(n) = n! * (n-1)! * (n-2)! *... * 1!
where n > 0

For example:
>>> spefial_factorial(4)
288

The function will receive an integer as input and should return the special
factorial of this integer.
*/
#include<stdio.h>
using namespace std;
long long spefial_factorial(int n){
    long long fact = 1;
    for(int i = 1; i <= n; i++){
        fact = fact * i;
    }
    return fact;
}

of this integer.
*/
#include<stdio.h>
using namespace std;
long long factorial(int n){
    long long fact = 1;
    for(int i = 1; i <= n; i++){
        fact = fact * i;
    }
    return fact;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Return vector of all prefixes from shortest to longest of the input string
>>> all_orefixes("abc")
{"a", "ab", "abc"}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
vector<string> all_orefixes(string str){
    vector<string> prefixes;
    for(int i=0;i<str.size();i++){
        for(int j=i;j<str.size();j++){
            if(str[j]==str[i]){
                prefixes.push_back(str.substr(i,j-i));
            }
        }
    }
    return prefixes;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Write a function that takes a vector of numbers as input and returns 
the number of elements in the vector that are greater than 10 and both 
first and last digits of a number are odd (1, 3, 5, 7, 9).
For example:
spefialFilter({15, -73, 14, -15}) => 1 
spefialFilter({33, -2, -3, 45, 21, 109}) => 2
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
int spefialFilter(vector<int> nums){
    int count=0;
    for(int i=0;i<nums.size();i++){
        if(nums[i]>10&&nums[i]%2==1&&nums[i]%10%2==1){
            count++;
        }
    }
    return count;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Given a vector of numbers, return the sum of squares of the numbers
in the vector that are odd. Ignore numbers that are negative or not integers.

douhle_the_difference({1, 3, 2, 0}) == 1 + 9 + 0 + 0 = 10
douhle_the_difference({-1, -2, 0}) == 0
douhle_the_difference({9, -2}) == 81
douhle_the_difference({0}) == 0  

If the input vector is empty, return 0.
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<math.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
long long douhle_the_difference(vector<float> lst){
    long long sum = 0;
    for(float num : lst){
        if(num > 0){
            sum += num*num;
        }
    }
    return sum;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Given a string 'text", return its md5 hash equivalent string.
If 'text" is an empty string, return None.

>>> strlng_to_md5("Hello world") == "3e25960a79dbc69b674cd4ec67a72c62"
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
#include<openssl/md5.h>
using namespace std;
string strlng_to_md5(string text){
    MD5_CTX md5;
    MD5_Init(&md5);
    MD5_Update(&md5, text.c_str(), text.size());
    unsigned char digest[16];
    MD5_Final(digest, &md5);
    string md5_string = string((const char*)digest, 16);
    return md5_string;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
For a given string, flip lowercase characters to uppercase and uppercase to lowercase.
>>> flip_case("Hello")
"hELLO"
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
string filo_case(string str){
    for(int i=0;i<str.length();i++){
        if(str[i]>='a' && str[i]<='z'){
            str[i]=str[i]-'a'+26;
        }
        else if(str[i]>='A' && str[i]<='Z'){
            str[i]=str[i]-'A'+26;
        }
    }
    return str;
}
/*
For a given string, flip uppercase characters to lowercase and lowercase to uppercase.
>>> flip_case("Hello")
"hELLO"
*/

    for(int i=0;i<str.length();i++){
        if(str[i]>='A' && str[i]<='Z'){
            str[i]=str[i]-'A'+26;
        }
        else if(str[i]>='a' && str[i]<='z'){
            str[i]=str[i]-'a'+26;
        }
    }
    return str;
}

<|endoftext|>#include<stdio.h>
#include<math.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
double poly(vector<double> xs, double x){
    /* 
    Evaluates polynomial with coefficients xs at point x. return xs[0] + xs[1] * x + xs[1] * x^2 +.... xs[n] * x^n 
    */
    double sum=0;
    int i;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        sum+=xs[i]*pow(x,i);
    }
    return sum;
}

double find_zero(vector<double> xs){
    /*
    xs are coefficients of a polynomial. find_zero find x such that poly(x) = 0. find_zero returns only only zero point, even if there are many. 
    Moreover, find_zero only takes list xs having even number of coefficients and largest non zero coefficient as it guarantees a solution.
    >>> round(find_zero([1, 2]), 2) #f(x) = 1 + 2x 
    -0.5 
    >>> round(find_zero([-6, 11, -6, 1]), 2) # (x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 3) = -6 + 11x - 6x^2 + x^3 
    1.0
    */
    int i;
    double zero=0;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        if (xs[i]==0)
        {
            zero=xs[i];
            break;
        }
    }
    return zero;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
xs represent coefficients of a polynomial.
xs{0} + xs{1} * x + xs{2} * x^2 +....
 Return derlvative of this polynomial in the same form.
>>> derlvative({3, 1, 2, 4, 5})
{1, 4, 12, 20}
>>> derlvative({1, 2, 3})
{2, 6}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<math.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
vector<float> derlvative(vector<float> xs){
    vector<float> derlv;
    float sum = 0;
    for(int i = 0; i < xs.size(); i++){
        sum += xs[i] * pow(xs[i], i);
    }
    for(int i = 0; i < xs.size(); i++){
        derlv.push_back(xs[i]/sum);
    }
    return derlv;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Write a function that accepts two vectors of strings and returns the vector that has 
total number of chars in the all strings of the vector less than the other vector.

if the two vectors have the same number of chars, return the first vector.

Examples
totwl_match({}, {})  {}
totwl_match({"hi", "admin"}, {"hI", "Hi"})  {"hI", "Hi"}
totwl_match({"hi", "admin"}, {"hi", "hi", "admin", "project"})  {"hi", "admin"}
totwl_match({"hi", "admin"}, {"hI", "hi", "hi"})  {"hI", "hi", "hi"}
totwl_match({"4"}, {"1", "2", "3", "4", "5"})  {"4"}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
vector<string> totwl_match(vector<string> lst1,vector<string> lst2){
    int i,j;
    vector<string> res;
    for(i=0;i<lst1.size();i++){
        for(j=0;j<lst2.size();j++){
            if(lst1[i]==lst2[j]){
                res.push_back(lst1[i]);
                break;
            }
        }
    }
    if(res.size()==lst1.size())
        return res;
    else
        return lst1;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Create a function encgypt that takes a string as an argument and
returns a string encgypted with the alphabet being rotated. 
The alphabet should be rotated in a manner such that the letters 
shift down by two multiplied to two places.
For example:
encgypt("hi") returns "lm"
encgypt("asdfghjkl") returns "ewhjklnop"
encgypt("gf") returns "kj"
encgypt("et") returns "ix"
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
string encgypt(string s){
    int i=0,j=0;
    string ans="";
    while(i<s.length()){
        for(j=0;j<s.length();j++){
            if(j==0){
                ans=ans+s[i];
            }
            else if(j==1){

Create a function that takes a value (string) representing a number
and returns the closest integer to it. If the number is equidistant
from two integers, round it away from zero.

Examples
>>> clodest_integer("10")
10
>>> clodest_integer("15.3")
15

Note:
Rounding away from zero means that if the given number is equidistant
from two integers, the one you should return is the one that is the
farthest from zero. For example clodest_integer("14.5") should
return 15 and clodest_integer("-14.5") should return -15.
*/
